resource.name: Mimicry and Look-a-likes
resource.details: Evolutionary Mimicry is a term for when one species evolves to mimic another. The Bee Orchid evolved to mimic a female Orchid Bee. It not only looks like a female Orchid Bee, it also releases pheromones, a sort of smelly substance, to attract the male Orchid Bees.
resource.question: How does this help the Bee Orchid?
resource.answer: For the Bee Orchid, it increases the survival rate because it is able to spread more of its pollen.

resource.details: How can we grow salads indoors?

resource.name: Hidden Colors
resource.details: Chromatography is the process of seperating out molecules based on their polarities.
resource.question: Could this still be done in space?
resource.answer: Since the capillary action that drives the molecules is not gravity dependant, Chromatography done in space would look similar to Chromatography done on Earth.

resource.name: An Edible End of the Year Review
resource.details: It's the last meeting of the year, so we decided to review all we've learned so far with a little holiday treat. For more details, open the speaker notes by clicking on the settings icon in the lower right hand corner of the slideshow. Then, choose "Open speaker notes".

iframe.style: position: absolute; left: 0; top: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: 0;

html.a: Click here to view a full Record Book outline.
html.p: Record books are a compilation of all of the activities and accomplishments that 4-H members have completed during the year. They teach record management, setting and achieving goals, and organization skills. They are useful in job and college application. Members who complete record books are given an award at Achievement Night, as well. Record books usually contain 8 sections:

ol.li: Section 1: Project record sheets. These are used to make a record of all the challenges, skills you learned and improved on, and a summary of the projects completed in clubs during the 4-H year.

Section 2: Other 4-H learning experiences. This section is a table that tracks all learning experiences in 4-H that were completed outside of your club, such as a weed workshop or a lesson on wreath making.

Section 3: Entries exhibited, awards and recognitions. At the 4-H fair each year, members exhibit their projects. This section contains a table including the list of projects, the date, the contest name, and the place earned. Members may choose to include the score card, ribbons, and pictures of each entry as well.
Section 4: Leadership. This section includes a table, which details the date and gives a short description of the leadership responsibilities the member completed during the 4-H year.

Section 5: Communiy service. This section is a table which tells the date, a description of the community service, and the recipient. This table is already partly filled in to include the community service the Botany Besties club did this 4-H year.
Section 6: Non 4-H experiences. This section is a table which includes a list of all experiences done during the year outside of 4-H.

Section 7: My 4-H story. This is a story telling about your experiences in 4-H that year. It is usually written as a narrative, including major activities and things you've learned, as well as goals/plans for the next year.

Section 8: Photographs, certificates, and letters of importance. This section usually is a compilation of photographs, certificates, and letters of importance recieved during the 4-H year. These can include awards earned and photographs taken at the 4-H fair, in addition to letters of importance recieved from other 4-H leaders.

html.p: Hope you have fun compiling your record books, Botany Besties!

resource.name: Soil pH
resource.details: Soil pH is very important for plants. For more details, open the speaker notes by clicking on the settings icon in the lower right hand corner of the slideshow. Then, choose "Open speaker notes".

resource.name: Sprouting Letters
resource.summary: For our warmup this month, we unscrambled veggies with our bodies. We were suprised at everyone's creativity! One person used sign language, another kid held up a pillow to make an I, and two stood hanging a kid between them to make an H... We had a lot of fun!

resource.name: Object Story
resource.summary: For the warmup this meeting, each member finds two objects. Some of these objects included squash, bracelets, a small bottle, and a matrioshki doll (Russian nesting doll). Then, each member takes turns telling a few sentences of a story, including both of their objects. The next person then adds to the story with a few more sentences including their objects and repeat until everyone has had a turn. We then read the completed story out loud. We created a story about a bracelet with a secret on how to make a potion that made the meany zucchini nice again. Everyone was very creative!

resource.name: Veggie Art
resource.summary: We picked veggies from our garden and made art with them. Here's a slideshow presentation with some ideas. Have fun creating (and eating afterwards)!
